bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, March 20, 1942

div1.p: Hench discusses studies of calcium and arthritis in relation to a possible venture by Kellogg's company. He comments on Hoffmann's professional status.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, March 20, 1942
div1.p: Thank you so much for sending Dr. Crain one of the framed paintings.

I hope there is not going to be any mixup in the time of your passage
through Rochester. I will be going East, as I told you, to Buffalo in about a
week.

As to the studies on calcium that you sent me, I wish that we could
talk in some detail. A letter will not permit me to discuss it satisfactorily
with you. Because in rheumatoid arthritis there is some loss of calcium from
the ends of bones of affected joints and because in osteoarthritis there are
certain calcified exostoses or bony spurs certain physicians have for years
and years felt that there might be some disturbance of the calcium metabolism.
Every now and then some doctor goes off half cocked and writes an article stating
that either the blood or urine calcium is abnormal in these diseases, but work
in well controlled laboratories has repeatedly showed no disturbance of calcium
metabolism. When I visited England a few years ago, a research worker in Guys
Hospital showed me reams and reams of statistics on carefully controlled calcium
metabolism studies. They had done months and months of work on it and could
find nothing to write about it. Another favorite idea is that that hardness of
the water has something to do with the local incidence of arthritis. Laymen
think that the hard water tends to harden the joints. This is also the bunk
The British Ministry of Health itself made a study several years ago, of its
incidence in communities where the water was very hard and also in communities
where the water was quite soft. They found no difference in incidence. All
of which makes me very unenthusiastic about the relationship of calcium to
arthritis. Another such research problem came out of Cleveland a few years ago
when a dentist, not a doctor, glibly talked about ionic calcium deficiencies in
arthritis. That blew up also. So you see, we have been thinking about the
problem but I am not interested in doing a lot of work that has a great chance
of being useless.
What shall I do with the photostated article you sent me?

Thank you indeed for the copy of Hoffman's letter. He certainly has
the missionary spirit if he wants to tell you, a layman, all about the pathology
of the liver in yellow fever. I am a little leery of the fellow because I never
heard of him before, despite two trips to Havana and conferences with many men
there, but maybe he is all that he says he is. Notice, however, that he continues
to sign himself with his professorial title. Having sent him fifty copies, I should
think he would be satisfied. I will not send him any reprints.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
